data.title: In the Pews: Visitation set for WGGS co-founder
data.meta_description: Visitation will be held from 3 to 6 p.m. today at the WGGS TV-16 studios in Taylors for Dove Broadcasting co-founder and vice president Peggy Joanne Thompson.
data.text:
Visitation will be held from 3 to 6 p.m. today at the WGGS TV-16 studios in Taylors for Dove Broadcasting co-founder and vice president Peggy Joanne Thompson.

She died Thursday in Greenville.

She and her husband, James H. Thompson, have produced Christian programming for more than 38 years. Joanne regularly hosted WGGS' program “Nite Line.” Other programs she hosted included “You Can Make It” and “The Jo-Mitch Show.”

In addition to reaching people through broadcast, she also did mission work in Appalachia, Romania and Moldova.

The funeral service for Thompson will be held at 3 p.m. Sunday at Faith Temple Church, 5080 Sandy Flat Road in Taylors, and burial will follow in the church cemetery.

WGGS studios are at 3409 Rutherford Road Ext. in Taylors.

Springs of Grace Lutheran Church, 7420 Highway 9 in Inman, will celebrate Shrove Tuesday with its annual All-You-Can-Eat Pancake Supper from 6 to 8 p.m. Tuesday. The meal includes pancakes, sausage, juice, coffee and milk.

The cost is $3 per person over age 12. Children 12 and younger will eat free.

Duncan First Baptist will hold a fundraiser March 12 to raise money for a mission trip to Nicaragua. The fundraiser is called The Big Stay 5k because the church's pastors will spend 48 hours in a replica of a Nicaraguan home.

“The pastors will live like the people live in the barrios of Nicaragua, with no running water, no electricity in a 10' x 12' home wrapped in black plastic,” according to a written statement.

The cost to participate in the Big Stay 5k race is $25, and a 1-mile fun run is $15. The fun run starts at 8 a.m. and the 5k race starts at 8:30 a.m. People can register online at www.thebigstay.com or the day of the race from 7:30 to 8:15 a.m.

Walkers also are welcome to participate.

The race starts at Duncan First Baptist and ends at The Big Stay Nicaragua home, to give participants insight into the needs of Nicaragua.

People can also make pledges per hour for the time the pastors live in the “plastic home.”

Pledges and donations may be made online at www.thebigstay.com or during the weekend of March 11-13.

Evangelist James Croft of Olustee, Fla., will preach revival services Sunday through Wednesday at Cudd Memorial Baptist Church, 1301 Boiling Springs Road.

“James has what some pastors have called a unique evangelistic ministry in that he is only 3 feet 10 inches tall. His size attracts the attention of adults, youth and children, allowing him the opportunity to share the gospel. He even has a pulpit that was made to fit his size. He jokingly says, ‘Have pulpit, will travel,' ” according to his website.

Sunday services start at 11 a.m. and 6 p.m. Sunday school breakfast will be served in the church's Christian life center at 8:30 a.m.

Services start at 6:30 p.m. Monday through Wednesday. Nursery provided for all services.

Croft leads the James Croft Evangelist Association. Read more about him at www.jamescroft.org.

The Spartanburg County Baptist Association will host its annual Benedict College Educational Rally worship service at 5 p.m. Sunday at the Greater Hopewell Baptist Church, 215 Hickory Drive in Startex.

The Rev. Ernest Pickens, pastor of Switzer Mount Zion Baptist Church in Woodruff, is the featured speaker. Special music will be performed by the 72-voice Associational Choir and Orchestra Leader. The Rev. Lewis Mills is host pastor and the Rev. Wendell L. Thompson Sr. is the moderator.

Central United Methodist Church, 233 N. Church St. will hold services throughout the Lenten season.

The Imposition of Ashes will be observed at 7 p.m. Wednesday in the sanctuary.

Lenten services will begin at noon every Wednesday through April 13 in the sanctuary.

A Service of Holy Communion starts at 7 p.m. April 21.

“Lent is the 40 days, excluding Sundays, before Easter. Beginning with the ‘Imposition of the Ashes' on Ash Wednesday and running through Easter Eve, April 23, Lent lasts a total of six weeks,” according to a written statement.

“Lent has become, over the centuries, a time during which Christians prepare themselves spiritually for the celebration of the resurrection. … This is the time in the Christian year that we engage in special disciplines: fasting, more prayer time, personal reflection and special acts of charity. We do this to keep Lent holy in preparation for the joy of the Resurrection.”

The Rev. Ian Walker, pastor of Christ Community Church of the Foothills, and his wife, Esther, will begin a six-week study on the second coming of Jesus on Sunday.

The study starts at 6 p.m. and will explore the New Testament book of Revelation. Christ Community is in the former Brannon's Restaurant on Highway 14 at the North Carolina state line.

Rejoice 1410 AM WRJD has joined with WOLI-AM 910 “to bring a new sound” to Spartanburg and other communities in the Upstate, according to a written statement.

Known together as “Rejoice Radio,” the WRJD/WOLI simulcast will have a combined audience of nearly 2.3 million listeners, according to the statement. Rejoice Radio can be heard online at http://1410wrjd.com.
